statement:
Suppose $X,Y$ are topological spaces and $f\colon X\to Y$ is a
continuous function. Then $f\colon X\to f(X)$ is continuous when $f(X)$
is equipped with the subspace topology.

Let us first note that using a propert[y]{} on , we have
$$X = f^{-1} f(X).$$ For the proof, suppose that $A$ is ope[n]{} in
$f(X)$, that is, $A=U\cap f(X)$ for some open set $U\subset Y$. From the
properties of the inverse image, we have
$$f^{-1}(A) = f^{-1}(U) \cap f^{-1}(f(X))= f^{-1}(U)$$ so $f^{-1}(A)$ is
open in $X$.
names: If $f\colon X\to Y$ is continuous then $f\colon X\to f(X)$ is continuous
